docs.lead_paragraph: Mother's milk is generally best, but not always. A study in the October issue of Environmental Health Perspectives, the journal of the National Institute of Environmental Health Sciences, shows that lead accumulated in a woman's bones can be released during pregnancy and transferred to breast milk during lactation. This can mean increased lead exposure for breast-fed infants, a risk if the mothers have been previously exposed to high concentrations of lead.
docs.abstract: Study by Australian and American scientists shows that lead accumulated in woman's bones can be released during pregnancy and transferred to breast milk during lactation, which could increase lead exposure for some breast-fed infants; Drs Brian L Gulson and Paul Mushak comment (S)
